children.value: This is the second project of Wes Bos's
We will be building a "clock" as using
s, some CSS animation and javascript. The idea is to replicate a minimalistic analog wall clock with an hours, minutes and seconds hand. Here is the video below -

.embed-container { position: relative; padding-bottom: 56.25%; height: 0; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; } .embed-container iframe, .embed-container object, .embed-container embed { position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; }
Here is the codepen for the starter file
See the Pen JS30-02-clock-a by Deepak Karki (@deepakkarki) on CodePen.
The HTML is simple and minimalistic
is the circular outer body of the clock, the
is the container for the hands. The three children divs represent the hour, minute and seconds hand respectively (as is evident by the class names).

The CSS is slightly more interesting (and involved). The clock outline is just a div with the border radius and border width set. Some box shadow for the styling. I learnt that you can apply multiple box shadows to a single element, something I did not know before!
box-shadow: offset-x | offset-y | blur-radius | spread-radius | color
. You can have multiple box shadows by comma separating the values as seen below. You can learn more about the box-shadow property @
is the container which holds the three hands. The height of each hand is 6px, so to account for it the container is moved up by 3px.
/* places it in between (the clock-face's translateY(-3px) takes care of the offset) */
gives the point at which the rotation transform is to take place - default would be at the center of the hand, but we want it to rotate around the right endpoint. Setting
The hands by default are at
which is horizontal, we set the transform to
to set them all in a vertical position -
give the animated effect when changing the angle of the hands.
Now the javascript bits! We can break it down into the following steps -
Extract the hours, minutes and seconds
Map the hours, minutes and seconds to corresponding degrees of the hands
Now the whole loop should run every second, let's abstract the update logic in the
Now all the logic that goes into the
Extract the current sec, min, hour
Map the time to degrees of the corresponding hands
Here the 90 represents 90 degrees that is to be added to set the hands to 12 O'clock (which by default they point to 9 O'clock). Rest is simple mapping from one range to another.
That is pretty much it! Put it all together and you get the finished version of the clock. The codepen with the final code below -
See the Pen JS30-02-clock-b by Deepak Karki (@deepakkarki) on CodePen.
